questions.question_text: Which of the following connector types can be plugged into a device both right-side up and upside down?
A network administrator would like to increase network bandwidth to 1Gbps between two office buildings that are 0.5mi(805m) apart. Which of the following would be the BEST solution?

discussion.content: I understand why fibre it correct but surely Cat 6 is cheaper?

comments.content: Yes, Cat 6 cable is cheaper, but if you use Cat 6 cable you reduce performance. If you use Single Mode Fiber (SMF) then you will be able to connect the two buildings without affecting performance.
Cat 6 only has a range of 100m before signal attenuation occurs.

Cat6a is 100 meters
Standard Cat6 is only 37-55 meters before performance starts to suffer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
mutual authentication for multiple services (SSO)

questions.question_text: A user is experiencing issues synchronizing a smartphone. The user is able to connect to individual services, but each requires a different password. Which of the following needs to be configured to allow the user to access web services securely with a unique password?

discussion.content: Cable testers are able to not only check for a broken or improperly crimped/punched cable, but can also test for length and correct pinout, both of which are critical to properly function. A toner/probe will simply help you track a cable location. A multimeter will allow you to test for continuity, but only if you have both ends in close proximity and only one of the eight wires at a time.
I was thinking that you have to find both ends of a cable in order to test it, so you would have to use the tone generator & probe first and then use a cable tester.

comments.content: Why wouldn't it be a cable tester, though?
Like KungPo said the technician has verified the link light is on so you're connected to something. Next step would be to find out what you're connected to.
I thought a multimeter was used to test for a broken cable. Cable tester to verify the wiring/wire map.

discussion.content:
Would not be the Toner & Probe the better answer?
A Cable tester will test & detect broken cables, but the Link LED is on. So the chance for a broken cable is not high.
More likely is, that the cable is just not connected to the correct port, at the client or Patchroom. A Toner & Probe will help to find out where it is connected.

questions.question_text: An end user is unable to connect to the network, and a technician has visually verified the lights on the back of the PC are active and there is no physical damage to the Ethernet jack. Which of the following tools should the technician use to continue troubleshooting the connection?

The graphics department has an issue with printing certain files. The printer does not print the complete image on larger files. A technician verifies the network speed of the printer is set to 1GB and that regular text files print without issue. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this problem?

choices.C: The users are not printing in post-script mode
choices.B: The print server is timing out
choices.D: The printer network connection is set to half duplex

discussion.content: I stand corrected. Some printers have ram sticks. So, it's A.
Laser printers has RAM as they store jobs in their own memory.
I have never heard of a printer having removeable/upgradeable RAM. I'm going with B on this one.

comments.content: Laser printers need to build the whole page in memory before they can print it. If the issue is occurring when trying to print detailed graphics it's likely the printer is running out or memory before it's finished building the page. Could cause it to only print part of the image or it could just not print the page at all.
I suppose you could rephrase is as "A printer with more RAM is needed"
